children.name: money for starting a new business or other activity
finance
children.definition: British /financingAmerican /ˈfaɪnænsǁfɪˈnæns, ˈfaɪnænsǁfəˈnæns, ˈfaɪnænsɪŋ,ǁfˈnænsɪŋ/  British money that you borrow or receive in order to pay for something important and expensive, for example for starting a business:
examples: nguồn tài chính
▪ We can’t continue our research unless we get more finance.
▪ The business plan is strong, but without financing, it will never work.
finance for
tài chính cho
▪ Scottish Homes is the nation’s biggest source of finance for house building.
obtain/raise finance : tăng tài chính, gom tài chính
▪ The next step was to obtain finance to develop the project.
▪ You’ll have to explain to them how you intend to raise the financing you need.
provide finance
cung cấp tài chính
▪ The European Investment Bank will provide finance for a variety of regional initiatives.
financenoun tài chính
[ U ] a supply of money
_corporate/personal/public finance
_the minister of finance/the finance minister
_You need to speak to someone in the financedepartment.
_The financecommitteecontrols the school's budget.

children.name: capital
children.definition: /ˈkæpɪtl, ˈkæpətl/  alargeamount of money that you can use to start a business or to pay for something that will later produce more money:
examples: vốn
▪ There is a shortage of capital for building new aircraft.
▪ Our return on capital has more than doubled since 1980.
investment capital: vốn đầu tư
▪ The plan is expected to create vast amounts of investment capital.
raise capital :tăng vốn, gom vốn
▪ Since the stockmarket crash, companies have been trying to raise capital by selling new stock.
capitalnounMONEY vốn; tư bản
[ U ] money and possessions, especially a large amount of money used for producingmorewealthor for starting a new business
_She leaves her capital untouched in the bank and lives off the interest.
_We'veput£20 000 capitalintothe business, but we're unlikely to see any return for a few years.

children.name: funding
children.definition: /ˈfʌndɪŋ/  money that agovernmentprovides to pay for education, theatre, music etc, not for business activities:
examples: vốn ( cấp bởi chính phủ để làm gì phi lợi nhuận )
▪ The President has yet to approve the additional funding needed to implement the program.
▪ If the funding were increased by just 12%, we could be close to a cure for the disease in five years.
funding of
sự tài trợ vốn của
▪ A special body advises the government on the funding of research.
funding for
sự tài trợ vốn cho
▪ Cuts in funding for the arts has lead to the closure of several theatres.
government/federal/state/public funding
Sự tài trợ vốn từ chính phủ/liên bang/nhà nước/công
funding provided by the government
▪ Congress banned federal funding of embryo research in 1995.
▪ The church is seeking an extra $300,000 in government funding.
lack of funding
thiếu vốn tài trợ
not enough funding
▪ School facilities have deteriorated over the past six years because of a lack of funding.
provide funding; cung cấp vốn tài trợ
▪ The Center will also provide funding to improve data collection and research.
fundingnoun[ U ] quỹ tài trợ
money given by a government or organization for an event or activity
_Ian is trying to get funding for his research.
_They received state funding for the project.

children.name: sponsorship
children.definition: /ˈspɒnsəʳʃɪpǁˈspɑːn-/  money that is provided by a company or by the government to pay for someone to do something or pay for something such as a sports event, art show etc:
examples: tiền bảo trợ, tài trợ
▪ We are looking for sponsorship from local businesses.
▪ Companies can help projects by providing financial sponsorship, office space, or printing facilities.
sponsorship of
tiền bảo trợ, tài trợ của
▪ a ban on tobacco company sponsorship of sports events
government/state sponsorship
tiền bảo trợ, tài trợ chính phủ/nhà nước
▪ The exhibition received £50,000 in government sponsorship.
corporate sponsorship
tiền bảo trợ, tài trợ của doanh nghiệp
sponsorship from a private company
▪ Corporate sponsorship ensures that far more money finds its way into sport than would otherwise be the case.

children.name: bank rate
children.definition: baseratenounUKspecialized lãi suất ngân hàng( dùng bởi ngần hàng )

children.name: arate(= level of payment) decided by thegovernment or the Bank of Englandwhichbanks use when deciding how much to charge for lending money
examples: _Your mortgage interest payments are two percent below the base rate.

children.name: the smart money
children.definition: noun tiền khôn; đồng tiền khôn

children.name: money that isinvested(= given to companies hoping to get more back)by experiencedinvestorswho know a lot about what they are doing
examples: _The smart money is coming back into mortgages as the best investment now.

children.name: return
children.definition: verbEXCHANGE hoàn lại

children.name: to give a particular amount of profit in exchange for aninvestment
examples: _My investments return a high rate of interest.

children.name: compound interest
children.definition: compoundadjective kép
examples: used to refer to a system of paying interest in which interestis paid both on the original amount of moneyinvested(= givento companies hoping to get more back) or borrowed and on anyinterest which that original amount has collected over a period of time
_compound interestlãi kép (lãi cho vốn gốc cộng với lãi)
_The investment fund has achieved annual compound returns of 18.2%.

children.name: collateral
children.definition: nounspecialized vật thế chấp

children.name: valuable property owned by someone who wants to borrow money which they agree will become the property of the company or person who lends the money if the debt is not paid back
examples: _Sheused/put upher house as collateral for a loan.

children.name: interest
children.definition: /ˈɪntrɪst, ˈɪntrəst/  an amount of profit that you make at an agreed rate when youput money intoa bank or similar institution:
examples: lãi
▪ If you had half a million dollars you could easily live off the interest.
▪ John had put his grandfather’s money in the bank, and was getting $400 a monthin interest.
rate of interest; lãi xuất the agreed amount paid as interest
▪ The best rate of interest the banks can offer is around 14 percent.
high/low interest
▪ a high interest savings account
interestnounMONEY
[ U ] money that you earn from keeping your money in an account in a bank or other financial organization
You should put the money in a savings account where it willearninterest.

children.name: interest rate
children.definition: lendingratenoun(also)mainly UK
examples: lãi xuất ( mà ngân hàng cho vay )
the amount that a bank charges on money that it lends
_banks have raised their lending rates by 2%.

children.name: finance
children.definition: noun tài chính, ngành tài chính
examples: [ U ] (the management of) a supply of money
_corporate/personal/public finance
_the minister of finance/the finance minister
_You need to speak to someone in the financedepartment.
_The financecommitteecontrols the school's budget.

children.name: simple interest
children.definition: nounlãi đơn (lãi trả cho tiền vốn thôi, không tính cả lãi cộng vào vốn)
examples: money that is paid only on an original amount of money that has been borrowed orinvested, and not on the extra money that the original sum earns

children.name: capitalization
children.definition: vốn hóa ( vốn đã cổ phần hóa )
examples: capitalization,UK usuallycapitalisationnounMONEY sự tư bản hoá, sự dùng làm vốn
[ S or U ] the total value of a company'sshareson astock exchange

children.name: lending rate
children.definition: lendingratenoun(alsointerest rate)mainly UK
examples: lãi xuất ( mà ngân hàng cho vay )
the amount that a bank charges on money that it lends
_banks have raised their lending rates by 2%.

children.name: money
children.definition: noun tiền ( vốn liếng )
examples: the amount ofthe coins or notesthat one person has

children.name: interest
children.definition: nounMONEY lợi tức, tiền lãi

children.name: principal
children.definition: nounMONEY tiền vốn; vốn chính

children.name: interest
children.definition: /ˈɪntrɪst, ˈɪntrəst/  money that you pay for borrowing money, especially that you pay every year or every month at a fixed rate:

children.name: ▪ Credit companies charge huge amounts of interest.interest on
examples: ▪ What’s the interest on the loan?

children.name: sinking fund
children.definition: sinkingfundnounspecialized quỹ chìm; quỹ trả nợ; quỹ thanh toán
examples: money saved by a company or government for the payment of future debts

children.name: purse
children.definition: nounAMOUNT TO SPEND ví tiền, hầu bao
examples: [ C usually singular ]the total amount of money which anorganization or governmenthas available for spending
publicpurse: công khố, quốc khố
_Having a lot of people out of work places a large drain on thepublicpurse.

children.name: venture capital
children.definition: noun vốn mạo hiểm; vốn rủi ro

children.name: money that isinvestedor is available forinvestmentin a new company, especially a riskyone
examples: _They'll need to raise £1 million in venture capital if they're to get the business off the ground.

children.name: working capital
children.definition: noun vốn luân chuyển; vốn lưuđộng
examples: the money belonging to a company which is immediately available forbusiness use, rather than money it has ininvestmentsor property

children.name: coffers
children.definition: kho bạc
examples: the money that an organization has in its bank accounts and available to spend
_government/party coffers

children.name: all the money that a person, company etc has
money
children.definition: /ˈmʌni/ tiền
examples: ▪ My grandmother left me all her money when she died.
▪ The committee is meeting to discuss how the money should be spent this year.
make your money
kiếm tiền
earn all your money doing a particular type of business
▪ He had made his money as a butcher in Kingstown.

children.name: means
children.definition: /miːnz/ formalall the money that you have - especially when you are talking about whether you are able to pay for everything you need:
examples: tiền bạc, của cải, tiềm lực
have the means to do something
có tiền bạc để làm cái gì đó
▪ He had the means to pay, but he refused on principle.
beyond your means
vượt quá tiềm lực tiền bạc của bạn
costing more than you can afford
▪ I think private schooling would be well beyond our means.
▪ She’s been living beyond her means spending more than she can really afford to, and now the debts have caught her up.
within your means
trong khả năng tiềm lực tiền bạc của bạn
not costing more than you can afford
▪ She was required to pay a $500 fee, which appeared to be within her means.
▪ Money isn’t a problem. We simply live within our means do not spend more than we can afford to.
private/independent means
của cải, tiền bạc riêng/sung túc
money that someone has from property, investments etc rather than earning it by working
▪ He’s given up his lecturing job, but he does have private means.
▪ Many tropical countries welcome people of independent means as long-term residents.
limited/modest means
tài chính có hạn/khiêm tốn
used to say that someone only has a small amount of money
▪ The best choice for elderly people with limited means is index-linked certificates.
▪ A university professor who used his modest means to collect over 300 valuable artworks has donated them to the National Gallery.
means test
sự thẩm tra tài sản
an official check to find out whether someone is poor enough to need money from the state
▪ The Council is introducing means tests for housing tenants.
meansplural nounMONEY tiền bạc; của cải; tiềm lực
money, for example from an income, that allows you to buy things
_[ + to infinitive]Hehasthe meanstobuy half the houses in the street if he wanted to.

children.name: assets
children.definition: /ˈæsets/  all of the money and property that a company or person owns, and which they may sell or use if necessary:của cải, tài sản
examples: ▪ On her death, she wants all her assets to go to her husband.
assets of $1 billion/£300,000,000 etc
Tài sản 1 tỷ đô la/ 300,000,000 bảng Anh...
▪ With assets of just under $1 million, the business is still relatively small.
$1billion/£300,000,000 etc in assets
1 tỷ đô la/ 300,000,000 bảng Anh... trong tài sản
▪ Massachusetts Financial Services manages $43 billion in assets.
financial assets
của cải tài chính
▪ Tomorrow, the court will hear evidence relating to Simpson’s financial assets.
personal assets
tài sản cá nhân
owned by an individual, rather than a company
▪ The directors’ personal assets will not be at risk if the company does fold.
assetnoun tài sản của cải
[ C usually plural ] something valuable belonging to a person or organization which can be used for the payment of debts
A company's assets can consist of cash, investments, buildings, machinery, specialist knowledge or copyright material such as music or computer software.
liquidassets (= money or things which can easily be changed into money)

children.name: finances
children.definition: /ˈfaɪnænsɪz, ˈfaɪnænsəz, fˈnænszǁfˈnænsz, ˈfaɪnænsz/  all the money that a person, company, organization etc has, especially when this is regularly checked so they know about any changes in it:
examples: tiền của, tài chính
▪ An accountant handles the school’s finances.
▪ She wondered if they’d ever get all their bills paid and their finances in order.
family/personal finances
tài chính cá nhân/gia đình
▪ An investigation into his personal finances produced no evidence of fraud
▪ To help the family finances, she went back to work at a retail store after William was born.
public/government finances
Ngân sách chính phủ/công
▪ Indeed, Lebanon’s public finances and yawning trade deficit, do look depressing.
▪ Government finances are strained to the hilt, dealing with essential services.
drain somebody’s finances/be a drain on somebody’s financesto reduce someone’s finances over a period of time, usually by an amount they cannot afford to lose
làm cạn kiệt tài chính của ai đó
▪ Legal expenses had drained his finances, and he could no longer afford to pursue the case.
▪ Many of the housing agencies represent a severe drain on the state’s finances.
finances
the money which a person or company has
_We keep a tight control on the organization's finances.
_UK informalMy finances won'trun to(= I do not have enough money to buy) a new car this year.

children.name: savings
children.definition: /ˈseɪvɪŋz/  the money which you have saved, which is usually kept in a bank or some other financial institution :
examples: tiền tiết kiệm ( trong 1 tài khoản ngân hàng hay tổ chức tài chính )
▪ Your savings are safe with the Bank of America.
▪ I should just take the money out of my savings and pay off my credit card.
▪ Since we retired we’ve been living on our savings and a small pension.
life savings
số tiền dành dụm cả đời
all of the money you have saved
▪ He had invested his life savings in the new business.
retirement savings
tiền tiết kiệm lúc về hưu
the money you have saved so that you have something to live on when you retire
▪ Break yourself of the habit of borrowing from your retirement savings.
lose your savings
mất tiền tiết kiệm của bạn
▪ Investors lost their savings, and some businessmen went bankrupt.
sink your savings into somethingto spend all the money you have saved on a particular investment, plan etc
đem tất cả tiền tiết kiệm của bạn đổ vào cái gì đó
▪ He and his wife July sank their life savings into an unsuccessful attempt to build a marina on a reservoir in Colorado.
savings tiền tiết kiệm, tiền để dành
the money which you keep in an account in a bank or similar financial organization
_He spent all his savings on an expensive car.

children.name: resources
children.definition: /rɪˈzɔːsɪz, -ˈsɔːs-ǁˈriːsɔːrsz/  all the money, property, or goods that a company, organization, or country owns and that can be used to make more money or to provide services:
examples: nguồn lực
▪ We have to make the best use of the resources we’ve got.
financial/economic resources
nguồn lực kinh tế/tài chính
▪ The government must make more human and financial resources available for AIDS research.
limited/scarce resources
nguồn lực giới hạn/khan hiếm
used to say that the amount of money available is small
▪ With limited resources, the club cannot continue to function without donations from members.
allocate resources (to something)
phân phối nguồn lực (vào cái gì đó)
decide how much money will be spent on particular things
▪ The process for allocating resources to military intelligence is severely flawed.
devote resources (to something)
dành nguồn lực (cho cái gì đó)
to spend money on a particular thing
▪ Few firms devote significant resources to research and development.
pool your resources
góp vốn
share your money with other people, so that you can all use it
▪ She and I pooled our resources -- not much -- and hired a car for the weekend.
